subject: virtualization & distributed computing
raw:
Virtualization, hypervisors, distributed file systems, container orchestration.

<[silence]> Virtualization involves creating a virtual version of something, such as hardware platforms, storage devices, or network resources. <[silence]> It allows multiple operating systems to run on a single physical machine by abstracting the hardware layer. <[silence]> Hypervisors, which can be either Type 1 (bare-metal) or Type 2 (hosted), manage these virtual machines, providing isolation and resource allocation. <[silence]> This technology enhances resource utilization and simplifies system management by decoupling software from hardware constraints. <[silence]>

Distributed computing, on the other hand, refers to a model where components of a software system are shared among multiple computers to improve efficiency and performance. <[silence]> This model relies on distributed file systems that enable data to be stored and accessed across various nodes in a network. <[silence]> Each node in a distributed system can perform computations independently, contributing to the overall task. <[silence]> This setup enhances scalability and fault tolerance, as the failure of one node does not compromise the entire system. <[silence]>

Container orchestration is a significant aspect of both virtualization and distributed computing. <[silence]> It involves managing the deployment, scaling, and operation of application containers across clusters of hosts. <[silence]> Tools like Kubernetes automate these processes, ensuring that containers are efficiently distributed and resources are optimally utilized. <[silence]> This approach simplifies the deployment of complex applications, ensuring consistency across different environments. <[silence]>

Three related subjects are cloud computing, edge computing, and microservices architecture.
